Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Study of Dayside Reconnection Through Cusp Ion Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences (AGS) Post-doctoral Research Fellowship grant to support a young woman scientist just beginning her scientific career.
The project addresses a longstanding question in magnetospheric physics about where magnetic reconnection occurs on the dayside magnetopause. In particular it will address the question of the relative importance of antiparallel reconnection which is thought to occur when the magnetosheath magnetic field and the magnetospheric magnetic field are oppositely directed and component reconnection in which one component of the two fields is oppositely directed. Cusp magnetic field lines map the magnetopause. Information about dayside magnetic reconnection is contained in particle signatures in the cusp region. The approach is to run a global magnetohydrodynamic simulation of the solar wind, magnetosphere and ionosphere system and then to launch ions into the fields from the simulation. The distribution of test ions in the cusp region will be used to model cusp ion spectrograms as a function of the location and nature of the reconnection. The simulations will vary solar wind conditions including the interplanetary magnetic field (IMF) clock angle, the radial component of the IMF and the solar wind pressure. The theoretical spectrograms will be compared with Cluster spacecraft observations. This study will contribute to an understanding of relationship between the cusp ion signatures and dayside reconnection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project achieved the relation between magnetopause reconnection and dispersed cusp ion signatures during various IMF conditions using a global MHD model and a test particle tracing code. The followings are six significant results of this project. First, during due southward IMF, anti-parallel reconnection occurs along the equatorial plane and produces typical cusp ion dispersion, i.e., decreasing cusp ion energies with increasing latitudes. Second, during due northward IMF, anti-parallel reconnection occurs at the northern and southern lobes. These reconnections produce reversed ion dispersions, i.e., increasing cusp ion energies with increasing latitudes. Third, during weakly northward and strongly eastward IMF, intermittent antiparallel reconnection appears on the northeast and southwest sides of the magnetopause, producing double reverse dispersions. Fourth, during weakly southward and strongly eastward IMF, component reconnection appears near the subsolar magnetopause, while antiparallel reconnection appears at the low-latitude, northeast side of the magnetopause. The component reconnection produces dispersionless signature in the low-latitude cusp, while anti-parallel reconnection produces dispersed ion signatures in the high-latitude cusp. Fifth, parallel electric fields in the high-latitude magnetopause during northward IMF can produce typical ion energy dispersion at the high-latitude cusp although such signature is expected only during southward IMF. Last, frequent flux transfer events on the winter hemisphere during southward IMF can produce multiple dispersions more easily on the summer cusp than the winter cusp. This modeled relation can help data analysts to interpret the causes of observed cusp ion dispersions, and thus to further improve our understanding of dayside reconnection. Dr. Connor is working on the inclusion of her test particle tracing code to Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) at NASA Goddard Space Flight Center. When fully adopted in the CCMC, scientists can conduct Monte Carlo simulation of space plasma particles using any global MHD model of their choice.

 

Broad Impacts: This postdoctoral research fellowship provides great developmental opportunities for Dr. Connor, a young female Asian scientist. First, she could extend her research expertise from the dayside science to the MIT coupling dynamics. Second, she could build strong social network with scientists in her field by attending domestic/international conferences and conducting collaborative researches. Two of her collaborative studies are recently funded by NASA H-MMSGI and H-USPI programs with Dr. Connor as a co-I. Third, she could contribute to the space science community by convening conference sessions and reviewing proposals and papers. Last, at the end of this project, Dr. Connor was offered and accepted a tenure-track faculty position at the Physics Department, University of Alaska Fairbanks.
